awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CNS Core: Small: Secure and Efficient Mobile Edge Computing in Wireless Heterogeneous Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Future wireless networks will support massive energy-limited computation-constrained user equipment that are often required to execute latency sensitive yet computation-intensive tasks. Although technologies that can elevate local device computation capability and battery capacity have been substantially pushed forward, there still exists a huge gap between the high computation/processing demands and the low computation/battery capacities in user equipment. Mobile edge computing (MEC) allows user equipment to offload partial or complete computation-intensive tasks to the edge computing servers to save power and reduce latency. Inspired by recent advances in wireless technologies and challenges, the proposed research aims to explore a novel framework that can jointly consider communications and computations in a mobile edge computing-based wireless heterogeneous network to realize secure and efficient offloading and achieve desirable trade-offs among computation throughput, computation efficiency, latency, and user fairness.  The proposed research activities have significant potentials to revolutionize the next generation wireless network design by jointly considering edge computations and communications in delivering secure, latency critical, computation-intensive applications such as augmented reality/virtual reality, connected and autonomous vehicle, and remote medical diagnosis. It can significantly facilitate the understanding in the field of emerging mobile edge networks, which will play a key role in the modem society to realize smart environments with computation intensive mobile applications. 

The proposed research framework develops secure multiple access schemes during offloading, computation coordination and scheduling schemes for selecting user equipment and computation tasks to offload. The research will identify unique technical challenges and explore many new aspects in the mobile edge computing enabled wireless heterogenous networks, including  non-orthogonal multiple access, computing offloading mode selection, success interference cancellation decoding order design, hybrid multiple access analysis, and heterogeneous MEC coordination, driven by joint consideration on security, efficiency, and user fairness.  The theoretical framework formulation and analysis, engineering design guidelines for practical implementation and deployment will be obtained, and prototyping/simulation tools will be shared with the scientific research and engineering communities. The success of this project can greatly advance the understanding of the critical issues in the mobile edge computing-based wireless network design and contribute a new resource allocation framework that can remarkably improve the performance of future wireless network computing. The project will also both undergraduate and graduate students research opportunities with developing and deploying new wireless network technologies, thus serving the growing need for educating and training students, especially female students and students from underrepresented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has investigated mobile edge computing (MEC) environments in wireless heterogeneous networks with secure and efficient schemes. The proposed research aims at developing novel secure multiple access schemes during offloading, computation coordination and scheduling schemes for selecting user equipment and computation tasks to offload. The approaches include identifying unique technical challenges and explore many new aspects in the mobile edge computing enabled wireless heterogenous networks, including non-orthogonal multiple access, computing offloading mode selection, success interference cancellation decoding order design, hybrid multiple access analysis, and heterogeneous MEC coordination, driven by joint consideration on security, efficiency, and user fairness. Theoretical analysis and performance evaluation for novel secure multiple access schemes in mobile edge computing have been obtained.

The research activities have resulted significant potentials to enhancing the mobile edge computing-based wireless network design and contributing a new resource allocation framework that can remarkably improve the performance of future wireless network computing. The project investigated a new mobile edge computing paradigm to meet the ever-increasing computing demand and energy/latency requirements. The research also improved security and privacy in mobile edge computing paradigm, which is one of the most important requirements for the MEC services. The project advanced the understanding in MEC-based wireless network design to achieve secure computation offloading and to optimize performance metrics such as secure computation efficiency, secure computation throughput, user equipment energy consumption, latency, as well as user fairness, which are expected to play a key role in the modem society to realize smart environments with extensive computation intensive mobile applications.

During the four years of the project, the project team investigated two of the most challenging issues of emerging mobile edge computing-based wireless network design, and studied high offloading efficiency and high offloading security aspects and achieve desirable trade-offs among computation throughput, computation efficiency, latency, and user fairness. The project team proposed novel approaches of comprehensive study on multiple access techniques, computation offloading mechanisms, resource allocation and coordination schemes to optimize multiple performance metrics and also study their trade-offs.

Both partial offloading and binary offloading mechanisms were considered in the study. In partial offloading, a computation task can be partitioned into two parts, one for local computing and one offloaded to the MEC server for computing. In binary offloading, the computation tasks cannot be partitioned so that they can be either completely locally computed or completely offloaded to the MEC server. An example for binary offloading is channel estimation, in which the raw data samples are correlated and need to be jointly computed altogether. Based on that, the project team investigated the multi-objective driven computation offloading with heterogeneous MEC servers. More specifically, various research activities were conducted:

-   Secure computation efficiency driven computation offloading with OFDMA access

-   Secure computation efficiency driven computation offloading with NOMA access

-   Secure computation efficiency driven offloading with a hybrid multiple access

-  Secure computation efficiency and secure computation throughput driven partial computation offloading

-  Secure computation efficiency and execution cost driven partial computation offloading

-  Multi-objective driven binary computation offloading

-  Secure computation efficiency driven offloading and coordination

-  Secure computation efficiency and user fairness driven computation offloading and coordination

-  Secure computation efficiency driven robust computation offloading and coordination

-  Develop secure and efficient federated learning framework in the mobile edge computing

Computer simulations were developed to evaluate the performance and tradeoffs and validate the theoretical results for secure and efficient mobile edge computing in wireless heterogeneous networks. As part of the comprehensive study, theoretical results to achieve optimal performance for secure and efficient mobile edge computing in wireless networks, as well as practical engineering design rules and guidelines for implementation and deployment of secure and efficient mobile edge computing in wireless networks, were obtained in the series of studies above. The research activities of this project have significantly revolutionized the field of mobile edge computing in wireless heterogeneous networks and have a significant impact on design of secure and efficient mobile edge computing in next generation wireless networks.

In total, three PhD students and one MS student as well as one REU student have been partially supported through this project. They received valuable training in wireless edge computing, federated learning, and semantic communications, including algorithm development, implementation of simulation software and analysis tools, as well as conducting experiments and analyzing results. This experience is preparing them to be workforce-ready in the wireless networking field. One of the PhD students is now a tenure-track faculty member at an U.S. university, the two others will be graduated within the next few months.
